importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the article indicates the timeline of the heist, which occurred just after the Louvre opened on Sunday, 19 October 2025.
The theft took place at 9:30 a.m. local time, coinciding with the museum’s opening, suggesting a deliberate timing to exploit high foot traffic and low security vigilance.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The heist occurred within minutes of the Louvre opening, indicating a pre-planned, rapid operation during peak visitor access and low security presence.
The entire heist lasted just seven minutes, showing a highly coordinated and efficient execution typical of professional criminal operations.

keyTakeAways: Thieves stole high-value historical jewelry from the Louvre’s Apollo Gallery, including a tiara, necklace, and brooches from the French Crown Jewels, with eight of nine items still missing.
The perpetrators used a truck-mounted ladder and an angle grinder to force open a window, indicating pre-planning and technical expertise.
One item, the crown of Empress Eugénie, was damaged during the heist and contains 1,354 diamonds and 56 emeralds.
No injuries were reported, but the museum remained closed for security and evidence preservation.
A detailed list of stolen items includes a single earring, an emerald necklace, emerald earrings, a reliquary brooch, and the tiara and corsage bow brooch of Empress Eugénie.
The suspects were unarmed but threatened guards with angle grinders and used a yellow vest to disguise themselves as workmen.
Police found tools including two angle grinders, a blowtorch, gasoline, gloves, a walkie-talkie, a blanket, and a crown at the scene.
An attempt to set fire to the truck was foiled by a security officer, highlighting the presence of a potential cover-up or diversion.
Investigators are considering foreign interference and have opened a case for aggravated theft by an organized gang and criminal conspiracy.
French President Emmanuel Macron condemned the act as an attack on national heritage and emphasized that the stolen items will be recovered and the perpetrators brought to justice.
The Louvre, which holds global cultural treasures like Leonardo da Vinci’s Mona Lisa, is under heightened security scrutiny following the incident.
Experts like Christopher Marinello of Art Recovery International warn that thieves might melt or recut stolen jewelry, risking irreversible loss of heritage integrity.
This is the first major robbery at the Louvre in over a century, with Paris mayor Ariel Weil noting the meticulous planning and rarity of such an event.

summaryOfNewsArticle: In a highly coordinated seven-minute heist that occurred just after the Louvre in Paris opened on 19 October 2025, thieves stole eight of nine items from the French Crown Jewels, including a tiara, necklace, and brooches worn by queens and empresses. The attackers, believed to be a team of four, used a truck-mounted ladder and an angle grinder to force open a window in the Apollo Gallery, where they removed valuable royal artifacts. One item, the crown of Empress Eugénie, was damaged, and a yellow vest used for disguise was found at the scene. No injuries were reported, but the museum was closed for security and evidence preservation. French officials, including President Emmanuel Macron, Interior Minister Laurent Nuñez, and Culture Minister Rachida Dati, condemned the attack as a severe blow to national heritage. Investigators are exploring foreign involvement and have opened a formal case for aggravated theft and criminal conspiracy. Experts warn that thieves may melt or recut the jewelry, risking irreversible loss of cultural integrity. This marks the first major robbery at the Louvre in over a century, highlighting the vulnerability of even the world’s most secure cultural institutions.
title: Thieves steal ‘priceless’ jewelry from the Louvre in 7-minute raid
